The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,000 for the first time, as investors carried the bull market past another milestone. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ Page D1. ] Other major share indexes also set records for the second consecutive day. [ D10. ]
Markets

The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,000 for the first time, as investors carried the bull market past another milestone. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ Page D1. ] Other major share indexes also set records for the second consecutive day. [ D10. ]
Corporate bond prices soared as investors sought higher yields than those available from Treasury issues. [ D16. ]
Prices for copper, silver, platinum and palladium rose strongly on the futures markets. [ D17. ] The dollar closed higher. [ D17. ] The Economy

The Supreme Court ruled that savings and loans can create paper losses for income tax purposes by swapping low-value mortgages. [ D1. ] The Court also ruled that international airline passengers cannot recover damages for mental anguish. [ B12. ]
President Bush signed legislation early this morning to end the national railroad strike. [ B8. ]
The Financial Accounting Standards Board is embroiled in an unusual skirmish over an appointment. [ D6. ] Companies

Strong drug sales at Bristol-Myers Squibb and Warner-Lambert led to record growth in profits in the first quarter. [ D1. ] Bristol-Myers asked doctors to refrain for now from using a breast implant linked to cancer in animals. [ B13. ]
Robert Maxwell will sell up to 49 percent of the Mirror Group to the public. The Daily News may be included later. [ D1. ]
Rich's, a landmark in downtown Atlanta, will close the huge store on July 13 after five years of losses. [ D3. ]
A bankruptcy court decision that would have let CNBC, buy its arch rival, Financial News Network was overturned. [ D19. ]
General Dynamics reported that operating earnings fell 9 percent, with sharply lower sales of military aircraft. [ D8. ]
Coca-Cola reported a 13.2 percent earnings increase in the first quarter, to a record $320.9 million. [ D2. ]
The parent company of American Airlines lost $195.6 million in the first quarter. [ D8. ]
Philip Morris's profit rose 21.5 percent for the first quarter. American Brands' profit rose 10.9 percent for the period. [ D5. ]
Harcourt Brace bondholders rejected an increased bid by General Cinema and the two companies broke off merger talks. [ D19. ]
The owners of Kermit the Frog accused Disney of "outright theft" of characters like Kermit and Miss Piggy. [ D19. ]
Michelin will cut at least 16,000 jobs from its worldwide work force by the end of next year. [ D4. ]
A.T.& T. had a modest gain in net income, while GTE reported a sharp decline in earnings. [ D5. ]
NCNB reported a decline of 8.4 percent in first-quarter profit because of problems with bad loans. [ D21. ] International
The chairman of the Export-Import Bank said Reagan and Bush had not exerted pressure on export guarantees for Iraq. [ D1. ]
Mexico assured California smog authorities that American companies would notbe able to escape pollution controls. [ A20. ]
A Bush Administration interagency policy group recommended retaliation against Tokyo over public works construction. [ D6. ]
Egypt may not get the level of aid it was promised from the rich Arab gulf states. [ D6. ] Today's Columns
The E.P.A. is expected to expand protection for some lenders. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [ D2. ]
A company has applied the technology of video conferences to focus groups. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [ D19. ]
